dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Probably confined to the littoral zone, over a firm substrate (Ref. 4983).  Gut contents of the specimens which were examined consisted mainly of Trichoptera larvae and sand-grain cases, but a few larval chironomids and baetids were also identified (Ref. 558).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.description:
Depth: 0 - 7m.
Recorded at 7 meters.

Habitat: demersal. Probably confined to the littoral zone, over a firm substrate (Ref. 4983). Gut contents of the specimens which were examined consisted mainly of Trichoptera larvae and sand-grain cases, but a few larval chironomids and baetids were also identified (Ref. 558).

dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Witte, F., de Zeeuw, M.P. & Brooks, E. 2010. Haplochromis chromogynos. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
VU
Vulnerable

Red List Criteria
D2

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2010

Assessor/s
Witte, F., de Zeeuw, M.P. & Brooks, E.

Reviewer/s
Darwall, W. & Smith, K.

Contributor/s

Justification
The population density of this species was known in the past. The current population density not known, and the species has declined since the 1970s but has been confirmed to still occur in Lake Victoria in low numbers. The threat responsible for its dramatic decline in the early 1980s was the introduction of the Nile Perch (Lates niloticus) to Lake Victoria. It appears that the population trend is starting to increase, however the biggest threat to this species now is increased hybridisation as a result of decreased water transparency. It is not known to what extent this is affecting different areas of the lake, but its current distribution is likely restricted to only a few locations, and it is therefore assessed as Vulnerable.
